6E444A4E8EF24001BCC93D71E3C9ED97.description: Apply the steps necessary to achieve self-selected healthenhancing goals.

1CF277C61E51401AB7406CD4A1B8C7C7.description: Recognize and establish the supports necessary to implement the health promotion action plans.

C19BEF1571A34EA599137456141D9CDC.description: Develop and use criteria to evaluate the implementation of health promotion action plans.

78252723DAA644679C37873854DDD609.description: Distinguish and use criteria to assess the design elements of health promotion action plans.

6BEFDF153FDF47B59F3FA41A1C9FB500.description: Plan the required steps to complete the health promotion action plans.

E8600E26606A482E862352A4F2F37E34.description: Discuss the elements of effective action planning for health promotion.

ABE99BCB6D2049D5B5CDD439CD2D7715.description: Design, implement, and evaluate three eightday action plans that demonstrate responsible health promotion related to comprehensive approaches to safety, non-curable infections/diseases, romantic relationships, healthy food policies, addictions, tragic death and suicide, chronic illness, and sexual health.

0FB76C61FF2948DAA79B3F758F047FC7.description: Apply decisions that will improve personal health and/or the health of others.

B9D0FC71CE3B48CBBDDF7C24166C2CE1.description: Evaluate goal statements to ensure they are clear, specific, measurable, and achievable.

8D6A47097206426397A804830E92A745.description: Create a health promotion goal statement that addresses health challenges and/or embraces health opportunities.

D0AB9ABF2D404D1B8D168CA76C170F91.description: Discuss processes used to set goals and make decisions that promote health.

73CD893BE3A94A2DAC4394EF2DD6B47D.description: Assess personal skills for the purposes of promoting health.

ADF2A4EA654F475FA4A633F709E84785.description: Analyze the health opportunities and challenges and establish personal health promotion goal statements related to comprehensive approaches to safety, noncurable infections/diseases, romantic relationships, addictions, tragic death and suicide, chronic illness, and sexual health.

CC31CC34D825476C92A8724B428128B0.description: Establish criteria and use them to evaluate strategies/ alternatives.

6F5B6B664D214D628576D0B4A61D9773.description: Generate strategies/alternatives to promote health in their community.

EC8DE40B17ED4E2BAAEB2A570D52B54E.description: Examine the health promotion needed in the local community.

6BBA31921CF84DF8ABC6E4A1F7402D91.description: Review the determinants of health and the health action policies as important aspects of health promotion.

A868DDCF16EB451B9CE661150B357ED2.description: Discuss the role of health promotion in decision making.

21AB40E27B93447BBE72DED4FD0EB919.description: Assess the role of health promotion in making healthy decisions related to comprehensive approaches to safety, non-curable infection/diseases, romantic relationships, healthy food policies, addictions, tragic death and suicide, chronic illness, and sexual health.

D970302C4225412CAE83F3DB3BBDDDC3.description: Make informed decisions based on health-related knowledge.

BDA84C36DCED49CE96A6C6E021574239.description: Establish a common and informed understanding of differences that exist in relation to sexuality and determine what differences are respected and protected in Canadian Human Rights legislation.

63DC88FB4C7D4C9DA59D885D281AC95E.description: Determine the behaviours and local resources/supports that can help to attain positive sexual health outcomes.

D5C5A56C18F440548A92A1A1AA466D4F.description: Use self-knowledge and understandings to promote sexual health with family, friends, partners, and community.

AEDF15A3FAE04552BD045BF20DF8D111.description: Determine the personal benefits of taking action to enhance sexual health and prevent/reduce sexual health problems.

50D1D6ADE2B644FFA5EEBE978A9A5D76.description: Articulate the influence of alcohol and other drugs on sexual attitudes and behaviours.

8985EDF49B7D4C5CA31CC26419CD2A14.description: Examine the strategies of personal commitment (see Grade 7) that are required to commit to one’s standards/decisions related to healthy sexual behaviour.

AB769C83944043FCB7E25C1FD8B19D22.description: Clarify personal standards (see Grade 6) that influence sexual health decisions.

EF6DEA8DE6A24F27A30FC5FD71E5762C.description: Determine how attitudes and behaviours may interfere with or enhance sexual health.

A42A748029F348CB9F881B735C5E2078.description: Evaluate the potential outcomes of sexual health attitudes and behaviours.

2D4CAF6775FC40F6B09C76E794EE2267.description: Assess how to raise, discuss, and negotiate sexual health issues with partners.

D1FEC4B7533A4BB3B9390888F778B278.description: Discuss sexual health choices that reduce the risk of healthcompromising consequences.

13BD37B7CFFA414DA37A7465DA0AA6DC.description: Analyze abstinence as the healthiest and safest sexual choice for young people.

C8D4D953514249DB8CDFFA995D98D949.description: Acquire knowledge that is appropriate for students’ levels of development, and directly relevant to their own sexual health needs including: an informed understanding of sexuality, prevention of sexual health problems, including pregnancy and sexually transmitted infections (STIs), enhancement of sexual health.

3011E51B838845B19169FA824C95F0BE.description: Examine personal attitudes about sexual health.

A8FFB930B0EA4B38BAC8488DE77C7CC5.description: Develop and demonstrate the personal insight, motivation, and skills necessary to enhance and promote sexual health and avoid health-compromising sexual attitudes and behaviours.

74283F6FEB854424B0010548B9C3F918.description: Appraise the in/formal community supports (grade 8) and health promotions and services for individuals and families living with chronic illness.

48EFD71675C04BD1B5F43441FAD03C1C.description: Examine the needs of individuals and families living with chronic illness.

DA144E48641740998E8E405005B0E6C8.description: Examine the challenges that exist in the community for people who are infected with/affected by chronic illness and propose possible solutions

0FFD8C2B7EAF41ED88DBDADDA24D90A7.description: Investigate agencies, organizations, and other sources of support for people who live with chronic illness.

2A60ECB5D54049B6888B7436BCFB7D32.description: Examine the disabilities associated with particular chronic illnesses (e.g., arthritis, visual/hearing impairments, multiple sclerosis, Parkinson’s).

26AF103F5ED0479BB5A16EB409965338.description: Investigate how people affected by chronic diseases are the same/different from others.

0BDD1A850E1C42318DE1E7E207F72E1B.description: Examine the similarities and the differences between an acute and chronic illness.

A0F6E5EB40AB40019234996738A52292.description: Analyze and question the stereotypes associated with people infected with/affected by chronic illness

47027629D4824F45B7E57D9D4E200AA2.description: Discuss the causes, symptoms, treatment, and prognosis of student-identified chronic illnesses (including physical and mental illnesses).

4F1E5624166847298A6A0D1A1FA5535B.description: Explore personal thoughts, feelings, and questions about chronic illnesses

95B674C9E5C84EF88B29CAE6FE785E7C.description: Evaluate and respond to a variety of sources of, and information about, chronic illness.

BF923383759D4B2EBF31101A6A064B92.description: Assess the ways self, family, and community facilitate healthy living for people with chronic illness.

D6EB31773831460B9AAD6E8C0FF0E779.description: Illustrate the healing (i.e., mental, emotional, spiritual) that is necessary for self, family, and community when a tragic death or suicide occurs.

3A4240F472F44FA5BC1E856FD82778B4.description: Communicate a list of community and/or provincial agencies or organizations that provide support for those considering suicide or coping with the tragic death of a friend or family member.

74DE99AE1D69489483631B8CBAA223E5.description: Examine ways to support self if contemplating suicide (e.g., call a crisis telephone support line, draw on the support of family and friends, set up frequent appointments with a mental health professional and request telephone support between appointments, get involved in self-help groups, talk every day to at least one person you trust about how you are feeling, seek help from the emergency department of a local health center/hospital, talk to someone who has ‘been there’).

6C6880B1D013429FBA49C5468D208E63.description: Recognize strategies to prevent or reduce the risk of a suicide attempt (e.g., getting help from a trusted adult).

79BE2E65DA4444DA9529FB71CC9B67D3.description: Investigate local and provincial health promotions to reduce tragic death (e.g., work safety promotions, traffic safety promotions) and suicide (e.g., part of curriculum).

5D44D640D5414CFEB754136203ECCF6B.description: Investigate and communicate Saskatchewan and Canadian trends in teen suicide and tragic death.

3AA9F87107324EACBB67292A6E5EC9CE.description: Discuss the impact of suicide and tragic death on the wellbeing of the individual, family, and community.

97F10B855DEE40EE9611B68EB5BA2D2F.description: Analyze the factors that may increase the risk for suicide (e.g., having a serious physical or mental illness, feelings of guilt, victim of abuse, abusing alcohol or drugs, experiencing a major loss, such as the death of a loved one, breakups/ divorce, unemployment, isolation).

F5A619993A294B32976EA773EE1E122C.description: Investigate and articulate warning signs of suicide (e.g., repeated expressions of hopelessness, helplessness, or desperation; behaviour that is out of character, such as recklessness in someone who is normally careful; signs of depression - sleeplessness, social withdrawal, loss of appetite, loss of interest in usual activities; a sudden and unexpected change to a cheerful attitude; giving away prized possessions to friends and family, making a will; making remarks related to death and dying; or an expressed intent to commit suicide).

84C548EE758B4136A35565D0CD3CD247.description: Express insights regarding community beliefs about suicide.

483EB5E8136549ADA2CF2CB5569B1AAC.description: Evaluate and respond to a variety of sources of, and information about, tragic death and suicide.

D41E7EEBBA914374B7D5AA5D05FF6170.description: Analyze tragic death and suicide as distressing community issues and appraise what supports and health promotions exist in the community to address these issues.

5B65325A447244F6A92B59AAFA11A2B9.description: Explore and describe the strengths within own family and cultural heritage, and of the struggles and challenges family and ancestors have faced related to addictions.

C0252C86E41B4B1ABA8C7FA619479E6F.description: Evaluate laws pertaining to tobacco use, alcohol use, drug use, and gambling.

2AA50215D88742D79BE1C71691573212.description: Assess community supports and services related to addictions.

BCE24D04BCD54442AA4933485C964975.description: Assess family and community norms and expectations regarding addictions.

F210E367680E4FDBAF42D4D0CF93E0F7.description: Distinguish between the responsible and irresponsible use of traditional, prescription, and over-the-counter drugs (including tobacco).

4B688A632AA344EB82336ADC65D3C2B9.description: Investigate how addictions affect the well-being of the environment.

FE66D8BF032E4D5B9D7ECF25C233E20F.description: Examine possible consequences of addictions on the health of self, family, and community.

24329F2E2C394DB5B0820C4365BD063A.description: Determine and practise the communication skills necessary to clarify personal standards regarding addictions.

533BA9E93ECA485C908CE24ADAC7658C.description: Evaluate and respond to sources of, and information about, addictions.

5A7DFBEDC4514F639B7E4532A951D803.description: Determine situations where youth may feel pressured/ tempted to smoke, chew tobacco, drink, gamble, or use drugs.

20B754E03E9A4573A18FBF435FE00520.description: Evaluate personal knowledge in terms of what is known and what needs to be learned about addictions

978F06A33D4D4A34A9862362F8CAB75C.description: Analyze the health, economic, and social supports and challenges of addictions (e.g., tobacco, shopping, alcohol, gambling, Internet, drugs) on self, family, community, and the environment.

E1718B3742AD44E39D257F2BA9271603.description: Determine and examine the actions/priorities that will bring about the greatest improvement to new and/or existing food policies.

F0FA4548FAC24D099CFD2CA671134F0A.description: Analyze the existing community/school food policies based on Canada’s Food Guide and other reputable sources.

2741C454BA2344E0916E3C393DB2C571.description: Examine the existing food policies in the school and/or community

45564C38346A49329CF344F98975E010.description: Determine the leadership skills that can be used in promoting a healthy food policy

27803ABA76F44124AFA767DE77554D06.description: Analyze the influences on the development and implementation of healthy food policies

968D6E10F6B54CE8A5C886690347EDDF.description: Investigate how Canada’s Food Guide has changed over time, speculate on the reasons for the changes, and determine possible effects on healthy food policies

08B2CF9F714942EA8FD495C901DE9D2C.description: Establish criteria (from Canada’s Food Guide) for healthy food policies

3A7054AE1F364941AFCAA9D059D24E48.description: Investigate and document principles of healthy food policies (i.e., one principle is the policy should be based on Canada’s Food Guide).

5DDCD7319C354EAF9FF9C0A769109779.description: Compare examples of healthy food policies.

866F62F4405B4737A49847170387E865.description: Evaluate and respond to a variety of sources of, and information about, healthy food policies.

7D3E94F4DF1C4FC786C5F263421F08FC.description: Evaluate a variety of healthy food policies and plan to participate in the development, revision, and/or implementation of a healthy food policy (e.g., fundraising, feasts, canteen sales, extra-curricular events) in the community (e.g., home, school, arena, youth center).

40CC636B377243EFBA4B951D9485BF32.description: Analyze how the following might assist in planning to promote health: appraise the assertiveness skills needed to set limits early in dating relationships (see Grade 7), examine how community norms might influence the support strategies (see Grade 8) available for healthy dating relationships, analyze the support strategies needed by someone who has experienced relationship violence and identify and practise the leadership skills needed to promote healthy dating relationships.

083EEF32C32545FDB4EE500CFBDC6D05.description: Analyze “relationship violence” in the context of family and community norms.

2FCC330F2D7C47DE9DD551C4A3703C63.description: Examine how family, cultural, and community expectations influence decisions of setting limits and agreeing to them early in romantic relationships

B5A63F8979E34F9692D4E8FF2709D127.description: Assess why some young people choose not to become involved in romantic relationships.

CA2B4992B48143B5840C0B07F714BF33.description: Assess individual, family, and community expectations for dating.

0782B0E6BA0B4DBC86ABF125F4BFD6CD.description: Determine how community and cultural norms might influence the strategies of personal commitment (introduced in Grade 7) required to set limits in healthy dating relationships.

D628079AA60E4D25B49F4E3178D50498.description: Interpret how community and cultural norms might influence the personal standards (introduced in Grade 6) and the limits one sets for dating relationships.

8244884FB54A41F3AF317806CA723D03.description: Categorize similarities and differences that exist among cultural norms and expectations regarding romantic relationships.

6AD2B306DB004DB8B39CFC5508D7AF70.description: Compare why and how people became involved in romantic relationships in the past and become involved in the present.

7172BFCA45D74D92A2F416C239A4CEAE.description: Evaluate and respond to a variety of sources of, and information about, romantic relationships.

DEDEC42E09FC4CE4899921C9DF1C8A01.description: Analyze the norms and expectations (e.g., community, cultural) associated with romantic relationships as a means to effectively plan for related health promotion.

1999A9543C824557A5862C1FA8820E3C.description: Examine health promotion strategies that reinforce and/or address the stigma associated with HIV/AIDS.

E28C50CFAD4748ABBF39894AFFA3134B.description: Determine that risky behaviours are often more prevalent in vulnerable/marginalized populations and discuss why these populations may be more at risk.

C058F2CA2B5F4CD5A483050E2C7B321F.description: Analyze how some non-curable infections, including HIV and Hepatitis C infection, are linked to risky behaviours, not to particular groups of people, and examine the stigma associated with risky behaviours (e.g., intravenous drug use, unprotected sex).

C1396FAC2B9B4FB380FDE57C831FF6AE.description: Determine the effects of stigmas of association with/ advocacy for those living with/affected by HIV/AIDS and/or Hepatitis C.

1AA142D0113F424E8A9347380CD1A4C5.description: Identify and question stigmas often attached to people who advocate for those infected with HIV and Hepatitis C.

43D8CE4C7EEF4F79BB038F2A0970A354.description: Examine the impact of the stigmas associated with HIV/ AIDS and Hepatitis C on the individual, the family, and the community.

961E1998DA824546AAB506569909B684.description: Examine stigmas associated with non-curable infections/ diseases, including HIV/AIDS and Hepatitis C.

5DC0F60F0183453EB2F5F2314042E5EC.description: Evaluate and respond to sources of, and information about, the provincial, national, and international impact of HIV/AIDS and Hepatitis C.

9D48623D4D1D49A693D9D9CD1188A978.description: Interpret, critique, and question the stigma associated with individuals, families, and communities living with/affected by noncurable infections/diseases, including HIV/AIDS and Hepatitis C and for those who advocate for them.

0F43658A8D13402CBE3EACD9B9032979.description: Propose how existing community safety promotions/ strategies could be more comprehensive.

1EDE5B6864144A0ABFE5A9DA4E76F67A.description: Determine the overlap/alignment of the safety approaches in the community

B9F0D56D77654525B3CACF7A8CF9B940.description: Analyze safety promotions/strategies that involve multiple partners, environments, and supports

8E07BAD26A274483A507E9009E3D3439.description: Explore how safe environments support the building of a sense of self and connections to others.

737A608044A84FCEB0C89D389C86DA95.description: Examine how unsafe situations affect the physical, mental, emotional, and spiritual well-being of self and others.

2F07058BA1574686A5822C853A9BBAC0.description: Assess how assertiveness skills (see Grade 7) can help to protect self, others, and the environment.

6DC6092328CA49B883CF5ECCB1A049AA.description: Investigate examples of comprehensive safety approaches.

6033460963E647BAB54FD8B9273E5EBA.description: Investigate the safety promotions/strategies in the community.

A9B2CD3DA3804AC0A4601FBF4D7DCB20.description: Examine safe/unsafe practices in the community that endanger/enhance the well-being of young people and analyze why these practices occur.

2A4CF2FEB2CB45BA86373CDC6C136A24.description: Examine situations when personal safety may be in jeopardy.

3AA5C29B608A43DBA91648045C24EDB1.description: Assess and communicate effective strategies to respond to signals of danger in familiar and unfamiliar situations.

910407F50F884C69B0B0AD1056F8B315.description: Investigate internal and external signals of danger in familiar and unfamiliar situations in the community

21837CFB21EA4D989FF2404B7641BDB0.description: Use the appropriate language with which to talk about comprehensive health approaches to safety (e.g., determinants of health, environments).

58FE4BC10E454FC4B423351A24F7B85E.description: Evaluate and respond to a variety of sources of, and information about, safety in the community.

212688974E814234A8A6935FB26326F5.description: Analyze how the well-being of self, family, community, and the environment is enhanced by a comprehensive, community approach to safety.

9D172BFA34C740CBB6E96F106B665CC4.description: Assess how the strategies of health promotion (i.e., strengthen community action, develop personal skills, create supportive environments, reorient health services, build healthy public policy) impact decision making and the health of self, family, community, and the environment.

719A8C11FC1D44E0B221DDA9883B803D.description: Examine how the determinants of health (e.g., education, income and social status, physical environments, biology and genetics) are interconnected and need to be addressed when promoting the health of self, family, community, and environment.

1688DDD985F9401C890BC6F06317210D.description: Assess the leadership skills needed/used in health promotion and related decision making.

DC17B0E593C543EF805BBC63FDED1208.description: Investigate and analyze examples of health promotion in one’s community.

70D182CDDA594214A9B04D95EFFCAB68.description: Examine health-enhancing behaviours that have increased due to the positive influence of health promotion (e.g., designated drivers – SGI, increase in physical activity – in motion).

069C78FC38FF4931AB6934FF932644A4.description: Examine local decisions that promote health.

853D789C27194686AC00CC47971D2CFD.description: Evaluate and respond to a variety of sources of, and information about, leadership skills

9AAFB8514DBD452B9F459C6DD7EAF622.description: Develop informed conclusions about the importance of leadership skills and health promotion in healthy decision making.

3502BF025A6B4CA689F9D44DD980F3BC.description: Develop the understanding, skills, and confidences necessary to take action to improve health.
